Construction type, use of bridge: Suspension bridge carrying the National Road over the Ohio River
Damage: Deck destroyed; towers left intact and remain in use today
Reason: Torsional movement and vertical undulations caused by wind

Damage: Span from anchorage to first pier destroyed
Reason: Inaugural train run conducted before temporary trestle work was replaced by permanent structure
Weight (two trains on the same trestle)
Washout
Sabotage by Confederate partisans during US Civil War.
Winter flood caused a debris build-up which shifted the bridge trestle.
Washaway

Construction type, use of bridge: Iron vehicular bridge (for pedestrians and carriages) over the Rock River
Reason: Large crowd assembled on one side to view baptism ceremony; bridge design flaw

Construction type, use of bridge: Wooden beam bridge over the Genesee River
Reason: Fire
Possible fatigue failure of cast iron elements

Damage: Estimated $15,000 worth of damage to the bridge and cars combined. Bridge was repaired.
Reason: Train derailment due to insecure railroad switch on the northbound side of the bridge.

Construction type, use of bridge: Iron railroad bridge collapses under train
Reason: Poor construction[6]
12 died when caisson flooded, 4 died when beam broke, 21 died when truss fell into river
Collapsed because of a sudden washout
Swing span struck by the steamer Northern Wave.
Washed out under pressure from debris during high water

Damage: Complete loss, plus two trolley cars destroyed
Reason: Collapsed a week after being resurfaced; poor steel, metal fatigue, and a previous impact by another bridge swept downstream during a flood

Construction type, use of bridge: Steel overhead truss bridge, vehicular traffic
Reason: Believed to have been weakened by heavy trucks hauling shale crossing the bridge in prior months
Bus drove across the drawbridge when it was open.
Two trucks were crossing the bridge when one struck a tie rod causing the bridge to collapse. One truck fell 15 feet to the creek bed, and the other escaped to safety.

Construction type, use of bridge: Road bridge, cable suspension with plate girder deck
Damage: Bridge completely destroyed, no persons killed. One dog killed and three vehicles lost.
Reason: Aerodynamically poor design resulted in aeroelastic flutter
Tanker Franz Klasen rammed the movable bridge supports, causing collapse
Three spans collapsed due to collision by the freighter Nicaragua Victory
Ship collision

Construction type, use of bridge: Kansas Avenue Melan Bridge for traffic between downtown and North Topeka
Reason: Structural deterioration
Faulty design and overload
Poor maintenance and overloading

Construction type, use of bridge: Vertical Lift Bridge over the South Brunswick River
Reason: Struck by the freighter African Neptune

Damage: Single span collapse, which however caused the closure and eventual demolition of most of the highway.
Reason: Poor maintenance and overloading
An ocean-going tanker ship, the 5,700 ton, 523-ft long Marine Floridian struck the bridge collapsing a section of the bridge.
Flooding undermined the lift span pier resulting in the western lift tower and roadbed span of the bridge collapsing into the Hudson River.

Bridge: Hood Canal Floating Bridge (William A. Bugge Bridge)
Damage: Western drawspan and western pontoons sunk; other sections survived.
Reason: Blown pontoon hatches combined with extreme windstorm

Damage: 1,200 feet (370 m) of southbound span, several cars and a bus destroyed
Reason: The freighter Summit Venture struck the bridge during a storm, causing the center section of the southbound span to collapse into Tampa Bay

Bridge: Old Fairmont to Wheeling Turnpike Covered Bridge Collapse
Construction type, use of bridge: Single-lane wooden-truss covered bridge built by Lemuel Chenoweth circa 1851–1853
Damage: Bridge floated downstream approximately 200 yards before crashing into bend in stream
Reason: Flash Flood of Paw Paw Creek Valley causing build-up of debris, with added weight of pedestrian Burns Fessler as the final person to cross

Construction type, use of bridge: Reinforced concrete spans on concrete support columns
Damage: Two vehicles drove into the opening left by collapsed span
Reason: Earthquake caused two spans to slip off supporting columns

Construction type, use of bridge: Double-deck suspended footbridge in hotel interior
Reason: Erroneous redesign of supporting member during construction when original design considered too hard to construct

Bridge: Cline Avenue over the Indiana Harbor and Ship Canal and surrounding heavy industry
Reason: 1,200 feet (370 m) of the bridge collapsed while under construction when a concrete pad supporting shoring towers developed cracks.

Construction type, use of bridge: Interstate 95 (Connecticut Turnpike) over the Mianus River
Damage: 100-foot (30 m) section of the northbound lanes fell into the Mianus River
Reason: Metal corrosion and fatigue/Deferred maintenance

Bridge: Schoharie Creek Bridge collapse Thruway Bridge
Construction type, use of bridge: I-90 New York Thruway over the Schoharie Creek
Reason: Improper protection of footings by contractor led to scour of riverbed under footings.
Flooding

Construction type, use of bridge: Northbound lanes of U.S. 51 over the Hatchie River
Reason: Shifting river channel, deterioration of foundation timber piles

Damage: Structure destroyed, remains demolished and removed. The ground-level Cypress Street is now Mandela Parkway.
Reason: Destroyed in Loma Prieta earthquake
50-foot (15 m) section of the upper deck and lower deck collapsed in Loma Prieta earthquake

Construction type, use of bridge: Pedestrian suspension bridge over the Little Red River
Reason: Destroyed by pedestrians swinging the bridge

Damage: 2,790 feet (850 m) of the bridge sank, dumping the contaminated water into the lake along with tons of bridge material
Reason: Heavy flooding of pontoons
Barge collision

Bridge: CSXT Big Bayou Canot rail bridge
Construction type, use of bridge: Railroad bridge span crossing Big Bayou Canot of Mobile River
Damage: Amtrak train Sunset Limited carrying 220 passengers plunged into water
Reason: Barge towboat, struck pier in fog; span shifted so next train derailed; impact of derailment destroyed span

Construction type, use of bridge: Single-lane temporary bridge in construction zone
Reason: Collapsed while being dismantled

Damage: Complete failure of two spans on I-5
Reason: Structural failure — support piers collapsed

Damage: Lost two of its seven western spans, A third span was damaged and later collapsed into the river.
Reason: As a result of rising flood waters and ice floe from the North American blizzard of 1996, when high floodwaters and a large ice floe lifted the spans off their foundations and swept them down the river.

Northbound right lane began to buckle during the morning rush hour and sagged a few feet below normal. Damage was a result of a violent failure of cross bracing members caused by extremely high stress concentrations in triaxial welds.

Damage: Structural damage required closure of the bridge
Reason: A fuel tanker overturned underneath the bridge, engulfing the bridge in fire

Construction type, use of bridge: Concrete bridge for vehicle traffic over Laguna Madre
Reason: 4 loaded barges veered 175 feet (53 m) west of the navigation channel and struck one of the bridge supports, causing a partial collapse of 3 sections measuring approximately 80 feet (24 m) each.

Construction type, use of bridge: Concrete bridge for vehicle traffic over Arkansas River
Reason: Barge struck one pier of the bridge causing a partial collapse
Hit by tornado with 100 mph winds
Car struck a truck carrying 8,000 US gallons (30,000 litres; 6,700 imperial gallons) of heating oil, igniting a fire that melted the bridge superstructure, causing collapse of the southbound lanes

As part of a construction project, a girder twisted, sagged, and fell onto I-70. An SUV was driving eastbound and struck the fallen girder; the top of the vehicle was torn off and the three passengers died instantly.[35]

Construction type, use of bridge: Two parallel trestle bridges crossing the eastern end of Lake Pontchartrain
Damage: The eastbound span was missing 38 segments with another 170 misaligned, while the westbound span was missing 26 segments with 265 misaligned.
Reason: After Hurricane Katrina on August 29, 2005, the old Twin Spans suffered extensive damage, as the rising storm surge had pulled or shifted bridge segments off their piers.
Collapsed during Mid-Atlantic United States flood of 2006
Tanker truck crash and explosion, resulting fire softened steel sections of flyover causing them to collapse.

Bridge: Minneapolis I-35W bridge over the Mississippi River
Reason: The NTSB said that undersized gusset plates, increased concrete surfacing load, and weight of construction supplies/equipment caused this collapse.

Construction type, use of bridge: Main thoroughfare into Oakville over Garrard Creek, Grays Harbor County
Damage: Majority to total collapse; temporary or permanent bridge is needed.
Reason: Collapsed under weight of a truck hauling an excavator[46][47][48]

Bridge: The Cedar Rapids and Iowa City Railway (CRANDIC) bridge
Damage: Three of the bridge's four steel spans were swept into the river along with 15 CRANDIC rail cars loaded with rock
Reason: During June 2008 Midwest floods
Collapsed due to tanker accident[56]
Two tension rods and a crossbeam from a recently installed repair collapsed during the evening commute, causing the bridge to be closed temporarily.

Bridge: Eggner Ferry Bridge over the Tennessee River
Damage: Span over the recreational channel of the river collapsed.
Reason: The MV Delta Mariner struck the bottom portion of a span of the bridge when travelling in the incorrect channel of the river.

Bridge: Jay Cooke State Park Swinging Bridge
Construction type, use of bridge: Pedestrian swinging wooden plank and cable
Damage: Multiple wooden planks washed away. Cables stayed intact.
Reason: Raging floodwaters
Oversized semi-truck load carrying drilling equipment from Alberta clipped top steel girder causing bridge collapse.

Damage: Two roadway bridge sections collapsed onto the rail line below.
Reason: A Union Pacific train T-boned a Burlington Northern Santa Fe train outside of Scott City, Missouri, at approximately 2:30 am. The impact caused numerous rail cars to hit a support pillar of a highway overpass, collapsing two sections of the bridge onto the rail line. Two cars ended up driving onto the collapsed sections, injuring three people in one vehicle and two in the other. Two people on one of the trains were also injured.[76][77]

Bridge: Hopple Street Overpass over I-75 Southbound
Reason: Old Northbound Hopple Street offramp totally collapsed onto roadway below during demolition[80]

Damage: Partial bridge collapse of north half of span
Reason: Partial collapse during demolition.
Abutment displacement due to stream meander, which caused abutment scour.

Damage: Bridge collapsed and washed away during flooding caused by severe rainstorm.
Reason: Destruction due to major flooding
An over-sized load hit the bridge, causing a section of the deck to fail

Damage: The foundation for one of the two piers was undermined by the landslide causing the pier to slide downhill with the earth around it and fail, and the deck to sag.
Reason: Massive rain and landslide

Damage: Investigation pending as to fire cause
Reason: Fire (allegedly arson) involving HDPE pipe and other construction materials stored under bridge critically weakened structure, which collapsed.

Bridge: Florida International University pedestrian bridge collapse
Damage: Complete Collapse on public road beneath.
Reason: Partially constructed concrete truss bridge with faux cable ties. One of two spans erected without faux cable ties or support tower. Faulty design, failure to follow proper procedures, and lack of redundancy all contributed to failure.
Overweight truck
